Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> writes:

> I can see arguments on both sides of the question. However, I'm a little 
> surprised at the amount of effort I'm having to expend to get people to 
> consider the question at all. The trouble people are going to evade it 
> suggests to me that this is a very uncomfortable point for a lot of 
> folks, and maybe the REST model (or at least HTTP) has some trouble
> here.
>
> So far I think the two or three folks who've actually addressed the 
> question square on have come down in favor of using POST despite the 
> safety of the operation.

I don't think that's fair.

When you were talking about the use case of credit card numbers this
was a very familiar anti-pattern to me. Something that people suggest
is confidential actually, on analysis, turns out not to be.

I cannot think of a use case of the kind of thing that you're talking
about.

Some things are confidential. Indeed I wouldn't want someone to look
over my shoulder and notice the contents of many web pages that I look
at on a daily basis (bank account, visa account, telephone bills,
etc...)

But I don't see that any of that has anything to do with GET or
POST. What's in the URL bar is the least of my concerns.
